document.docAuthor: Olmi, Massimo, Copeland, Robert S. & Noort, Simon Van
document.docTitle: Crovettia afra Olmi & Copeland & Noort 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Dryinidae of the Afrotropical region (Hymenoptera, Chrysidoidea)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Dryinidae of the Afrotropical region (Hymenoptera, Chrysidoidea)

heading.emphasis:
1.
Crovettia afra Olmi, Copeland & van Noort
, sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis . ♀ and ♂ of
Crovettia
with head and mesoscutum granulate ( Fig. 19 ); 2r-rs&Rs vein straight and with apex not broadened ( Fig. 18D ); metapectal-propodeal disc and propodeal declivity reticulate rugose.

Description . ♀ . Fully winged; body length 1.6–1.7 mm . Head black, except mandible testaceous; antenna testaceous; mesosoma black; metasoma brown; legs yellow-testaceous. Antenna clavate; antennomeres in following proportions: 5:5:4.5:4.5:4.5:4.5:4.5:4.5:4:7. Head dull, granulate; frontal line absent; occipital carina complete; POL = 5; OL = 3; OOL = 3.5; OPL = 3; TL = 4; greatest breadth of lateral ocelli shorter than OL (2:3). Mesoscutum and mesoscutellum dull, granulate. Notauli absent. Metanotum dull, rugose. Metapectal-propodeal disc dull, reticulate rugose, without transverse posterior keel; propodeal declivity with tracks of two longitudinal keels. Forewing hyaline, without dark transverse bands; 2r-rs&Rs vein straight and with apex not broadened (as in Fig. 18D ); pterostigma large and black, occasionally brown. Tibial spurs 1/1/2.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 18.
Crovettia
sp. ♀ n dorsal (A) and lateral (B) view.
Crovettia afra Olmi, Copeland & van Noort
sp. nov. : head in frontal view of ♂ specimen from Kenya, Muhaka Forest (C); forewing of holotype (D). Scale bar: A: 2.2 mm; B: 1.84 mm; C: 0.79 mm; D: 0.8 mm.
FIGURE 19. Crovettia afra Olmi, Copeland & van Noort sp. nov., ♂ holotype: habitus in dorsal (A) and lateral (B) view; head in frontal view (C); forewing (D).

FIGURE 20. ♂ genitalia of
Crovettia afra Olmi, Copeland & van Noort
sp. nov. : A: holotype; B: specimen from Madagascar, 21°15.99’S 47°25.21’E; C: specimen from Kenya, 3.30958°S 39.96538°E. Scale bar: A: 0.20 mm; B: 0.16 mm; C: 0.19 mm.

Etymology . The species is named
afra
after the collection site in the Afrotropical region.
